Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing and Modeling the Experience of Transfer Students in Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This STEP Type 2 project is a research study of engineering undergraduate students intended to provide new knowledge about transfer of these students between two year and four year colleges. The project is studying how transfer students differ from native students in demographics, outcomes, and trajectories. It explores the contribution of transfer students to the size and diversity of graduating classes, and searches for explanations for observed outcomes. The research team is studying the degree to which engineering students transfer across institutions and pursue undergraduate engineering studies using a longitudinal database of over 700,000 student records that have been previously assembled by the investigators. The qualitative component of this study relies on interviews and focus groups of transfer students to explore the factors that motivated them to transfer out of their institutions, exploring GPA and time-to-degree of engineering students for transfer and native students. The project is expected to contribute to published literature about student progression through the academic cycle and to provide information useful to administrators of colleges and universities for making policy changes about student participation and degree awards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Approximately 10% of all students who graduate from a four-year college with a degree in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) started their studies at a different institution. These transfer students are different from those who enter college for the first time—they tend to be older and different life experiences. Transfer students are an important potential source to increase the number of STEM students, who have a positive effect on the economy. As important, the community college population is much more diverse than the four-year college population, so transfer students can help colleges and universities diversify their student body in terms of race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status. A study of more than 5,000 STEM graduates who entered eleven institutions as transfer students reveals much about who transfers and how they do. Interviews of transfer students result in recommendations for institutions attempting to recruit more of them as well as recommendations for those who advise transfer students.

Based on this large-scale study, the fraction of transfer students that has graduated, left the institution, or is continuing after six years is similar to that of students starting college for the first time. Transfer students have a lower grades, but not in their engineering classes. The high school performance of transfer students—in terms of grades, rank, and standardized test scores—is lower, likely because this is one of the reasons that some students choose the transfer pathway. Transfer students are also more likely to be Hispanic/Latino and are older. Transfer students thus represent an opportunity to diversify engineering enrollment by race/ethnicity and age. Transfer students are more likely to attend part time, one indication that they represent socioeconomic diversity as well.

The study found notable differences between students who transfer from other four-year institutions and those who transfer from two-year institutions (community colleges and technical schools). Two-year transfers had similar grades overall to four-year transfers, but two-year transfers were less likely to fail a course. This was true for engineering and non-engineering courses. Two-year transfers were more likely to repeat a science course.

Several differences were found based on the gender of the transfer student as well. Compared to male transfer students, female transfer students are less likely to graduate (in engineering or anything else), have slightly lower grades, are more likely to fail a course and somewhat more likely to repeat a science course, and (as a likely result of those factors) attend longer. Although Black students were not strongly represented in the transfer population, Black transfers had similar grades and were more likely to graduate than non-Black transfers.

An important part of the study was interviewing 86 students who transferred to one of the participating institutions. This helped researchers understand how transfer students end up in that pathway and what institutions do that helps or hinders them. Transfer students generally started at their first institution because it was in some way a better fit—nearer to home, easier to be admitted, had more students like them, and/or more accommodating of their work and family needs. Some became transfer students as a “second chance” after an earlier, unsuccessful college experience. Although some had strategically chosen to transfer as engineering students from when they first entered their original institution, others only considered the possibility of studying engineering and the transfer pathway later on—some after being encouraged to do so.
